name: firebase-jest-testing
description: Tools for testing Firebase back-end features, using Jest.

//exports../firestoreTestingAdmin: ./src/firestoreTesting/admin.js   -- keeping away from 'exports' so a non-existing file would not cause other problems (pending Jest ES modules support for 'globalSetup')

scripts.ci_seq: npm run ci:rest && npm run ci:rules
scripts.//ci_par: concurrently -n rules,rest "npm run ci:rest" "npm run ci:rules"
scripts.ci:rest: firebase emulators:exec --project=bunny --config firebase.json --only firestore,functions "npm run _ci_init && npm run _ci_fns"
scripts.start:rest: concurrently -n emul,init "firebase emulators:start --project=bunny --config firebase.json --only functions,firestore" "GCLOUD_PROJECT=bunny npm run _start_rest_2"

--experimental-vm-modules: Needed for now (Aug 2020), to use native ES6 modules with Jest
--detectOpenHandles speeds up tests: This is weird, but consistent. If we keep it in 'npm test', the test execution is ~2x faster (as reported, per test).
Doing this, since it means our timeouts can be smaller.
peerDependencies: Force the downstream project to explicitly depend on 'firebase'. It would be wrong that we bring all that in.
However, use of '@firebase/rules-unit-testing' is seen as an implementation detail they should not worry about.

proper-lockfile: Unfortunately, node (14.8.0) does not provide OS level locking. There are multiple choices for this - this is

./package.json: Needed *at the application end* for Jest to be able to use the package (with the custom resolver hack).

start: Must use 'firebase emulators:start' so that the Emulators UI shows the data. This causes 'concurrently'
and 'wait-on' to be needed, as dependencies.
Update: Since 'firebase-tools' 8.7.0, the '--ui' parameter is there, but we're already used to this.
ci_par: Cannot launch two Firebase emulators, in parallel ('firebase' 8.7.0)
